item.title: being.
item.description: What is being as a part of epistemology? why do we practice art? Practice anything, no matter how well or how bad, we practice art as a act of becoming, for our soul to grow. ...

item.title: Economics as an engineer, a guide.
item.description: samples. 29.a 30.a behavioural economics invisible hand of the market: self-interest of individuals leads to the best outcome for society as a whole, in a free market economy, as rational actors are motivated by incentives.

item.title: Steady state error and PID controller
item.description: See also problem Problem√® 1 In Lab 4, We used a PD compensator to control our ball and beam apparatus. The transfer function of our PD compensator was as follows: GC‚Äã(s)=KD‚Äãs+KP‚Äã However, we did not use the compensator in this form.

item.title: MST with shortest path optimisation
item.description: Probl√®me 1. Consider we want to build McMaster Maps, the best online route planning tool in existence. The developers of McMaster maps have decided to represent road information in terms of a a massive graph in which nodes are crossing and the edges are the roads between crossings.

item.title: Attractor
item.description: A set of points described by a dynamical system. Some exhibits chaotic behaviour, see also Paul Bourke‚Äôs work Often create visually appealing patterns, but its applications range from physics to biology: how we understand weather patterns, bird migration patterns, quantum phenomena.

item.title: Shortest path and series-parallel graph
item.description: Probl√®me 1. A regional government wants to improve their existing infrastructure between a collection of towns T. In specific, the government want to build a minimum number of roads such that there is a route from each town to each other town.

item.title: Graph search and A-star

Consider a m√ón game board in which each cell has a numeric value, e.g: GHIJK‚ÄãA13123‚ÄãB24433‚ÄãC24112‚ÄãD34341‚ÄãE44114‚ÄãF21422‚Äã‚Äã A player starts the game with a token in the top-left cell (the cell GA in this example) and the player finishes the game by moving to the bottom-right cell (the cell KF in this example).

item.title: Automata
item.description: Q1: T/F, if F explain why. Q4: regular expression, 5 separate q Q2/Q3: DFAs and NFAs Product construction: ‚à© ‚à™ of DFAs Subset construction: NFA to DFA Quotient construction: State minimization Set theory Complement in Œ£‚àó: L=Œ£‚àó‚àíL associative: (A‚à™B)‚à™C(A‚à©B)‚à©C(AB)C‚Äã=A‚à™(B‚à™C),=A‚à©(B‚à©C),=A(BC).‚Äã commutative: A‚à™BA‚à©B‚Äã=B‚à™A=B‚à©A‚Äã null set null set ‚àÖ is the identity for ‚à™ and annihilator for set concatenation A‚à™‚àÖ=A and A‚àÖ=‚àÖA=‚àÖ set {œµ} is an identity for set concatenation {œµ}A=A{œµ}=A Set union and intersection are distributive over set concatenation A‚à™(B‚à©C) A‚à©(B‚à™C)‚Äã=(A‚à™B)‚à©(A‚à™C)=(A‚à©B)‚à™(A‚à©C)‚Äã Set concatenation distributes over union A(B‚à™C) (A‚à™B)C‚Äã=AB‚à™AC=AC‚à™BC‚Äã DFA DFA#definition Let Œ¥:Q√óŒ£‚ÜíQ, thus Œ¥^:Q√óŒ£‚àó‚ÜíQ Œ¥(q,c)‚Üíp therefore Œ¥^(q,w)‚Üíp regularity Important Œ¥^(q,œµ) Œ¥^(q,xa)‚Äã=q=Œ¥(Œ¥^(q,x),a)‚Äã Important a subset A‚äÇŒ£‚àó is regular if and only if there exists a DFA M such that L(M)=L Important All finite languages are regular, but not all regular languages are finite examples Show L is regular where L={x‚à£x%3=0‚à™x=œµ}, with Œ£={0,1} Three states, q0‚Äã,q1‚Äã,q2‚Äã, where q0‚Äã denotes the string mod 3 is 0, q1‚Äã denotes the string mod 3 is 1, and q2‚Äã denotes the string mod 3 is 2.

item.title: Atmospheric properties for exoplanets
item.description: Ref: slides features. H=œâmH‚ÄãgkB‚ÄãT‚Äã solid or dash solid q larger mean molecular weights? B: shallow features ‚áí higher mean molecular weights mass-metallicity trend Question Can we detect clouds in exoplanets? Clouds suppress atmospheric chemical signatures Important Introduced a degeneracy between cloud-top pressure and mean molecular weight clouds/winds on giant planets.

item.title: philosophy
item.description: Toute id√©e fausse finit dans le sang, mais il s'agit toujours du sang des autres. C'est ce qui explique que certains de nos philosophes se sentent √† l'aise pour dire n'importe quoi.

item.title: steady-state error
item.description: See also slides Important System type is the number of integrators in the forward path, thus value of n .

item.title: Alignment
item.description: See also: Overton Window and this blog on alignment research The act of aligning oneself with a particular group or ideology. This can be done for a variety of reasons, including: To gain social acceptance To gain power To gain resources Often known as a solution to solve ‚Äúhallucination‚Äù in large models token-generation.

item.title: Overton Window
item.description: also known as window of discourse A window into the ideas that frames ideas that people are prepared to entertain. All ideas outside the window are not seriously considered.

item.title: ethics
item.description: Closely connected to value theory, or moral philosophy. Kantian ethics presupposes that there is a universal moral law that applies to all rational beings, or his deontological ethics framework that based on ‚Äúcategorical imperative‚Äù.

item.title: Root mean square
item.description: See also: pdf probl√®me 1. The Root Mean Square (RMS) value of a signal f(t) that is periodic with period T is given by the equation T1‚Äã‚à´0T‚Äã(f(t))2dt‚Äã It can be shown that the RMS value of u(t)=Bsinœât is 2‚ÄãB‚Äã 1.a Square wave The square wave function is defined as: f(t)={10‚Äãif 0‚â§t<2T‚Äãif 2T‚Äã‚â§t<T‚Äã import sympy as sp t = sp.symbols('t') T = 2 RMS = sp.sqrt(1/T * sp.integrate(1, (t, 0, T/2))) RMS = 2‚Äã1‚Äã 1.b Sawtooth wave A sawtooth wave function is defined as: f(t)=T2A‚Äã(t‚àí2T‚Äã) import sympy as sp t = sp.symbols('t') T = 1 A = 0.5 f_t = 2 * A / T * (t - T/2) RMS = sp.sqrt(1/T * sp.integrate(f_t**2, (t, 0, T))) RMS = 63‚Äã‚Äã 1.c sine wave A general form of the sine wave can be written as f(t)=Asin(œât+œï) Amplitude is 2.3, no phase shift RMS = 2‚Äã2.3‚Äã probl√®me 2.
